intro: Humata seramensis, commonly known as the Seram humata, is a rare flowering plant native to the island of Seram in Indonesia. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its showy, trumpet-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in humid, shaded environments within lowland forests. Its leaves are heart-shaped and have a velvety texture, while its flowers range in color from white to pink. Due to habitat loss, Humata seramensis is considered endangered and is of significant interest to botanists and conservationists.
